elements.content: The dimeric molecule [Dy2(acac)6(MeOH)2(bpe)]·bpe·2MeOH (1, acac = acetyl­acetonate, bpe = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene) undergoes a solid-state ligand substitution reaction upon heating, leading to the one-dimensional chain [Dy­(acac)3(bpe)] n (2). This structural transformation takes advantage of the potential coordination of the guest bpe molecules present in 1. In both complexes the Dy­(III) ions adopt similar octacoordinated D 4d geometries. However, the different arrangement of the negatively charged and neutral ligands alters the direction of magnetic anisotropy axis and the energy states, thus resulting in largely distinct magnetization dynamics, as revealed by the CASSCF/RASSI calculations.
elements.clean_text: The dimeric molecule [Dy2(acac)6(MeOH)2(bpe)]⋅bpe⋅2MeOH (1, acac = acetylacetonate, bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene) undergoes a solid-state ligand substitution reaction upon heating, leading to the one-dimensional chain [Dy(acac)3(bpe)] n  (2). This structural transformation takes advantage of the potential coordination of the guest bpe molecules present in 1. In both complexes the Dy(III) ions adopt similar octacoordinated D 4d  geometries. However, the different arrangement of the negatively charged and neutral ligands alters the direction of magnetic anisotropy axis and the energy states, thus resulting in largely distinct magnetization dynamics, as revealed by the CASSCF/RASSI calculations.

elements.content: A Dy­(III) single-molecule magnet undergoes a structural transformation from a dinuclear complex to a one-dimensional chain upon solid-state ligand substitution reaction, which further varies the slow magnetic relaxation behaviors.
elements.clean_text: A Dy(III) single-molecule magnet undergoes a structural transformation from a dinuclear complex to a one-dimensional chain upon solid-state ligand substitution reaction, which further varies the slow magnetic relaxation behaviors.

elements.content: Single-molecule magnets (SMMs) bearing magnetic bistability and exhibiting slow relaxation of magnetization at molecular level have become the focus of considerable research efforts due to their potential applications in ultrahigh-density storage and quantum computation. Such super-paramagnetic behavior originates from the combination of strong magnetic anisotropy and large multiplicity of the ground state. This leads to a high energy barrier that hampers the reversal of magnetization, which results in a slow magnetic relaxation. Lanthanide (Ln) ions, like Dy­(III), have become the ideal candidates for researchers to construct SMMs due to their inherent large magnetic anisotropy derived from their large angular momentum quantum number (J).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Single-molecule magnets (SMMs) bearing magnetic bistability and exhibiting slow relaxation of magnetization at molecular level have become the focus of considerable research efforts due to their potential applications in ultrahigh-density storage and quantum computation. Such super-paramagnetic behavior originates from the combination of strong magnetic anisotropy and large multiplicity of the ground state. This leads to a high energy barrier that hampers the reversal of magnetization, which results in a slow magnetic relaxation. Lanthanide (Ln) ions, like Dy(III), have become the ideal candidates for researchers to construct SMMs due to their inherent large magnetic anisotropy derived from their large angular momentum quantum number (J).

elements.content: The interaction between the lanthanide center and the surrounding atoms leads to the zero-field splitting of the spin–orbit coupled ground state (2S+1LJ). This splitting has been demonstrated to be very sensitive to the crystal field in which the magnetic ion resides. The repulsive interaction between the aspherical electron density distribution of the metal and the electrostatic potential of the surrounding ligands has been proved to be the key factor for determining the energy levels, eigenstate composition, and the direction of magnetic anisotropy axis of the Ln­(III) ions. Moreover, a recent study on an Er-trensal complex indicates that covalency effects can also play an important role in determining low-lying energy spectrum and g factors of the ground Kramers doublet. Manipulation of the coordination sphere in lanthanide-based SMMs has been successfully utilized for tuning molecular magnetism thanks to the strong correlations between crystal field and magnetization dynamics. For example, the change of counter-anions in some distorted D 4d mononuclear Dy­(III) complexes results in a cis–trans isomerism of the chelate ligands, thus altering the magnetic behavior. In a second example, the replacement of one porphyrin pyrrole nitrogen atom by oxygen or sulfur in bis­(tetrapyrrole) Dy­(III) complexes results in enhanced energy barriers and in the appearance of butterfly-shaped hysteresis loops.
elements.clean_text: The interaction between the lanthanide center and the surrounding atoms leads to the zero-field splitting of the spin-orbit coupled ground state (2S+1LJ). This splitting has been demonstrated to be very sensitive to the crystal field in which the magnetic ion resides. The repulsive interaction between the aspherical electron density distribution of the metal and the electrostatic potential of the surrounding ligands has been proved to be the key factor for determining the energy levels, eigenstate composition, and the direction of magnetic anisotropy axis of the Ln(III) ions. Moreover, a recent study on an Er-trensal complex indicates that covalency effects can also play an important role in determining low-lying energy spectrum and g factors of the ground Kramers doublet. Manipulation of the coordination sphere in lanthanide-based SMMs has been successfully utilized for tuning molecular magnetism thanks to the strong correlations between crystal field and magnetization dynamics. For example, the change of counter-anions in some distorted D 4d  mononuclear Dy(III) complexes results in a cis-trans isomerism of the chelate ligands, thus altering the magnetic behavior. In a second example, the replacement of one porphyrin pyrrole nitrogen atom by oxygen or sulfur in bis(tetrapyrrole) Dy(III) complexes results in enhanced energy barriers and in the appearance of butterfly-shaped hysteresis loops.

elements.content: In 2010 Gao et al. reported a [Dy­(acac)3(H2O)2] mononuclear complex with SMM behavior that exhibits a butterfly-shaped hysteresis loop. Since then, many similar Dy­(III) β-diketone SMMs, with distorted D 4d geometries (Type I in ), have been prepared, and their magneto-structural correlations, in which the neutral capping ligand has been replaced by other moieties, have been studied.
elements.clean_text: In 2010 Gao et al. reported a [Dy(acac)3(H2O)2] mononuclear complex with SMM behavior that exhibits a butterfly-shaped hysteresis loop. Since then, many similar Dy(III) β-diketone SMMs, with distorted D 4d  geometries (Type I in ), have been prepared, and their magneto-structural correlations, in which the neutral capping ligand has been replaced by other moieties, have been studied.

elements.content:
L = neutral auxiliary ligands.

We report herein the successful transformation of a Dy­(III) β-diketone system from a Type I complex into a Type II analogue () by a solid-state ligand substitution reaction, which produces an alteration of the coordination sphere of the metal center. The substitution of the coordinated MeOH molecules around Dy­(III) ions by bpe guests not only leads to the structural transformation from a dimeric Dy­(III) complex, [Dy2(acac)6(MeOH)2(bpe)]·bpe·2MeOH (1), to a [Dy­(acac)3(bpe)] n chain (2), but also causes the rearrangement of the coordination atoms around the Dy­(III) ions, consequently changing the crystal field and modulating the magnetization dynamics.
elements.clean_text:
a L = neutral auxiliary ligands.  

We report herein the successful transformation of a Dy(III) β-diketone system from a Type I complex into a Type II analogue () by a solid-state ligand substitution reaction, which produces an alteration of the coordination sphere of the metal center. The substitution of the coordinated MeOH molecules around Dy(III) ions by bpe guests not only leads to the structural transformation from a dimeric Dy(III) complex, [Dy2(acac)6(MeOH)2(bpe)]⋅bpe⋅2MeOH (1), to a [Dy(acac)3(bpe)] n  chain (2), but also causes the rearrangement of the coordination atoms around the Dy(III) ions, consequently changing the crystal field and modulating the magnetization dynamics.

elements.content: All reactions and manipulations described below were performed under aerobic conditions. Metal salts were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were collected using a Quantum Design MPMS XL-7 SQUID magnetometer and a Quantum Design PPMS with VSM option. Polycrystalline samples were embedded in vaseline to prevent torquing. Alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility data measurements were performed with a 5 Oe ac field at frequencies between 0.1 and 1488 Hz. Magnetic hysteresis loops were continuously measured on VSM with the field ramping rate of 200 Oe/s. All data were corrected for the diamagnetic contribution calculated using the Pascal constants. The C and H microanalyses were performed on freshly filtered samples, which were taken out immediately from mother liquor, with an Elementar Vario-EL CHN elemental analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) intensities for polycrystalline samples were measured on a Bruker D8 Advance Diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.540 56 Å). The thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on a NETZSCH TG209F3 thermogravimetric analyzer in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 K/min.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Procedures

All reactions and manipulations described below were performed under aerobic conditions. Metal salts were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were collected using a Quantum Design MPMS XL-7 SQUID magnetometer and a Quantum Design PPMS with VSM option. Polycrystalline samples were embedded in vaseline to prevent torquing. Alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility data measurements were performed with a 5 Oe ac field at frequencies between 0.1 and 1488 Hz. Magnetic hysteresis loops were continuously measured on VSM with the field ramping rate of 200 Oe/s. All data were corrected for the diamagnetic contribution calculated using the Pascal constants. The C and H microanalyses were performed on freshly filtered samples, which were taken out immediately from mother liquor, with an Elementar Vario-EL CHN elemental analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) intensities for polycrystalline samples were measured on a Bruker D8 Advance Diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å). The thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on a NETZSCH TG209F3 thermogravimetric analyzer in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 K/min.

elements.content: [Dy2(acac)6(bpe)­(MeOH)2]·bpe·2MeOH (1). A mixture of Dy­(acac)3 (0.1 mmol) and bpe (0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 0.5 mL of MeOH. After it was stirred for ∼10 min, the resulting suspension was filtered. The filtrate was sealed in a 5 mL glass tube. Colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained for several hours at 5 °C. Yield: 76% based on Dy­(acac)3. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H60Dy2N2O14: C: 49.33, H: 5.57, N: 3.97; found (%): C: 49.43, H: 5.36, N: 3.72.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[Dy2(acac)6(bpe)(MeOH)2]⋅bpe⋅2MeOH (1). A mixture of Dy(acac)3 (0.1 mmol) and bpe (0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 0.5 mL of MeOH. After it was stirred for ~10 min, the resulting suspension was filtered. The filtrate was sealed in a 5 mL glass tube. Colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained for several hours at 5 °C. Yield: 76% based on Dy(acac)3. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H60Dy2N2O14: C: 49.33, H: 5.57, N: 3.97; found (%): C: 49.43, H: 5.36, N: 3.72.

elements.content: [Dy­(acac)3(bpe)] n (2) A mixture of Dy­(acac)3 (0.1 mmol) and bpe (0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 0.5 mL of MeOH. After it was stirred for ∼10 min, the resulting suspension solution was filtered. The filtrate was layered by 0.5 mL of isopropanol solution with 0.07 mmol bpe and then was sealed in a 5 mL glass tube. Colorless plate crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained after several hours at 5 °C. Yield: 69% based on Dy­(acac)3. Anal. Calcd (%) for C27H31DyN2O6: C: 50.51, H: 4.87, N: 4.36; found (%): C: 50.41, H: 4.94, N: 4.42.

After it was stirred for ~10 min, the resulting suspension solution was filtered. The filtrate was layered by 0.5 mL of isopropanol solution with 0.07 mmol bpe and then was sealed in a 5 mL glass tube. Colorless plate crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained after several hours at 5 °C. Yield: 69% based on Dy(acac)3. Anal. Calcd (%) for C27H31DyN2O6: C: 50.51, H: 4.87, N: 4.36; found (%): C: 50.41, H: 4.94, N: 4.42.

elements.content: As may be observed the Dy/bpe ratio (1:1) is the same in both complexes 1 and 2. However, the amount of bpe in both reactions is higher (1:2) and varies: 2 equiv of bpe are employed in the synthesis of 1, while 1.7 (1 in the first step plus 0.7 in the isopropanol layer) equiv of bpe are used to obtain complex 2. bpe is always added in excess to enforce its coordination and also to compensate the high oxygenphilic character of dysprosium. As may be observed, the nature of the solvent employed for crystallization seems to have a great impact in the final products; the {Dy} n chain (2) is obtained in isopropanol probably due to the lower polarity of this solvent, which facilitates the rearrangement of the neutral bpe ligand to fully act as a bridge between two dysprosium atoms.

However, the amount of bpe in both reactions is higher (1:2) and varies: 2 equiv of bpe are employed in the synthesis of 1, while 1.7 (1 in the first step plus 0.7 in the isopropanol layer) equiv of bpe are used to obtain complex 2. bpe is always added in excess to enforce its coordination and also to compensate the high oxygenphilic character of dysprosium. As may be observed, the nature of the solvent employed for crystallization seems to have a great impact in the final products; the {Dy} n  chain (2) is obtained in isopropanol probably due to the lower polarity of this solvent, which facilitates the rearrangement of the neutral bpe ligand to fully act as a bridge between two dysprosium atoms.

elements.content: Diffraction data for complex 1 was collected on a Bruker D8 QUEST diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) at 150 K. Complex 2 was recorded on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini R CCD diffractometer with Cu Kα, λ = 1.540 56 Å at 150 K. The structures of all complexes were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. Hydrogen atoms on organic ligands were generated in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Crystal data and structural refinements are listed in . Additional crystallographic information is available in the .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction data for complex 1 was collected on a Bruker D8 QUEST diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 150 K. Complex 2 was recorded on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini R CCD diffractometer with Cu Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å at 150 K. The structures of all complexes were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. Hydrogen atoms on organic ligands were generated in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Crystal data and structural refinements are listed in . Additional crystallographic information is available in the .

Ab initio CASSCF­(7,9) calculations (including 21, 128, and 98 states for sextet, quartet, and doublet multiplicities, respectively) were performed for complexes 1 and 2 using the Molcas 8.0 package. In both cases the structures were reduced to mononuclear Dy­(III) complexes like the ones shown in a,b, including all the methanol, bpe, and acac– ligands directly attached to the metal center. The all-electron ANO-RCC basis set was employed in these calculations, including the following contractions: Dy [9s8p6d4f3g2h]; O [4s3p2d1f]; N [4s3p2d1f] and [3s2p] for atoms directly attached or far away from the Dy center, respectively; C [3s2p] and H [2s].
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

Ab initio CASSCF(7,9) calculations (including 21, 128, and 98 states for sextet, quartet, and doublet multiplicities, respectively) were performed for complexes 1 and 2 using the Molcas 8.0 package. In both cases the structures were reduced to mononuclear Dy(III) complexes like the ones shown in a,b, including all the methanol, bpe, and acac- ligands directly attached to the metal center. The all-electron ANO-RCC basis set was employed in these calculations, including the following contractions: Dy [9s8p6d4f3g2h]; O [4s3p2d1f]; N [4s3p2d1f] and [3s2p] for atoms directly attached or far away from the Dy center, respectively; C [3s2p] and H [2s].

A view of the dinuclear {Dy2} unit and the hydrogen-bonded bpe molecules in 1 (b) and a segment of the {Dy} n chain in 2 (e). The packing diagrams of the dinuclear {Dy2} units and the guest bpe molecules for 1 (c) and the 1D {Dy} n coordination chains for 2 (f) along a axis. The red arrows are the potential coordination direction of guest bpe molecules. The hydrogen bonds are displayed as purple dashed lines.

elements.content:
The spin–orbit coupling was introduced as implemented in the Restricted Active Space State Interaction (SO-RASSI) approach and the magnetic properties were obtained with the SINGLE_ANISO code).

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure

The single-crystal X-ray crystallography data () reveals that 1 crystallizes in the P1̅ space group and contains one crystallographically independent Dy­(III) ion in the asymmetric unit. In complex 1, the Dy­(III) ion (a) is eight-coordinate (NO7) with a distorted square antiprism coordination geometry by three chelated acac–, one bpe ligand, and one methanol molecule. Four O atoms from two acac– ions serve as one square, while the remaining acac– ion, the O atom of methanol, and the bpe ligand offer three O atoms and one N atom for the other square. Such square antiprism coordination sphere of Dy­(III) center in 1 (Type I in ) is similar to some other reported complexes with general formula [Dy­(acac)3(L) x ] (where L can be mono- or bidentate with x = 2 or 1, respectively). A further SHAPE analysis () gives a square antiprism CShM value of 0.827 for 1, indicating the magnitude of deviation from the ideal D 4d symmetry. Each coordinated bpe ligand bridges two Dy­(III) ions through its two terminal N atoms, producing the corresponding dinuclear {Dy2} units (b) with a Dy···Dy distance of 14.71 Å. The guest bpe molecules are anchored through the N···H–OMe hydrogen bonds with the coordinated methanol molecules (c).
elements.clean_text:
The spin-orbit coupling was introduced as implemented in the Restricted Active Space State Interaction (SO-RASSI) approach and the magnetic properties were obtained with the SINGLE_ANISO code). 

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The single-crystal X-ray crystallography data () reveals that 1 crystallizes in the P1̅ space group and contains one crystallographically independent Dy(III) ion in the asymmetric unit. In complex 1, the Dy(III) ion (a) is eight-coordinate (NO7) with a distorted square antiprism coordination geometry by three chelated acac-, one bpe ligand, and one methanol molecule. Four O atoms from two acac- ions serve as one square, while the remaining acac- ion, the O atom of methanol, and the bpe ligand offer three O atoms and one N atom for the other square. Such square antiprism coordination sphere of Dy(III) center in 1 (Type I in ) is similar to some other reported complexes with general formula [Dy(acac)3(L) x ] (where L can be mono- or bidentate with x = 2 or 1, respectively). A further SHAPE  analysis () gives a square antiprism CShM value of 0.827 for 1, indicating the magnitude of deviation from the ideal D 4d  symmetry. Each coordinated bpe ligand bridges two Dy(III) ions through its two terminal N atoms, producing the corresponding dinuclear {Dy2} units (b) with a Dy⋅⋅⋅Dy distance of 14.71 Å. The guest bpe molecules are anchored through the N⋅⋅⋅H-OMe hydrogen bonds with the coordinated methanol molecules (c).

elements.content:
CShM Values Calculated by <italic>SHAPE</italic> 2.1<named-content content-type="bibref-group"> <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref42"></xref>,<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref43"></xref> </named-content> for the Dy­(III) Ions in <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t2fn1"></xref> complex SAPR-8 (D 4d ) TDD-8 (D 2d ) 1 0.827 1.217 2 0.501 2.536

SAPR-8 = square antiprism; TDD-8 = triangular dodecahedron.

Considering the coordination potential of the guest bpe molecules and that they have free nitrogen donor atoms, we speculate a solid-state ligand substitution reaction, where the methanol ligand could be replaced by bpe. This kind of reaction has already been observed in some flexible frameworks with specific oriented host–guest interactions. The thermogravimetry (TG) and the variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) were measured to probe such solid-state ligand replacement. When heated, complex 1 suffers a mass loss of 9.42% at ∼60 °C (Figure S2), which agrees with the complete desolvation of the coordinated and the guest MeOH molecules (9.07%). Moreover, the VT-PXRD further indicates the crystal transformation from 1 to a new complex above 65 °C (). Although the single crystallinity of 1 was lost during the structural transformation, luckily, through the change of synthetic condition (see ), the single crystals of complex 2 () suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The PXRD experiment (Figures S1 and S2) confirms that the as-synthesized complex 2 and the TG transformed powder are identical.
elements.clean_text: Considering the coordination potential of the guest bpe molecules and that they have free nitrogen donor atoms, we speculate a solid-state ligand substitution reaction, where the methanol ligand could be replaced by bpe. This kind of reaction has already been observed in some flexible frameworks with specific oriented host-guest interactions. The thermogravimetry (TG) and the variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) were measured to probe such solid-state ligand replacement. When heated, complex 1 suffers a mass loss of 9.42% at ~60 °C (Figure S2), which agrees with the complete desolvation of the coordinated and the guest MeOH molecules (9.07%). Moreover, the VT-PXRD further indicates the crystal transformation from 1 to a new complex above 65 °C (). Although the single crystallinity of 1 was lost during the structural transformation, luckily, through the change of synthetic condition (see ), the single crystals of complex 2 () suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The PXRD experiment (Figures S1 and S2) confirms that the as-synthesized complex 2 and the TG transformed powder are identical.

elements.content: Solid-state transformation from 1 to 2 monitored by VT-PXRD at different temperatures.
elements.clean_text: 2  Solid-state transformation from 1 to 2 monitored by VT-PXRD at different temperatures.

elements.content: As expected, the single-crystal structure of 2 shows that the terminal methanol ligand was replaced by the hydrogen-bonded bpe molecules when heated, thus confirming the solid-state ligand substitution. After the coordination of the guest bpe molecules, the {Dy2} units in 1 are connected with each other, resulting in the one-dimensional (1D) coordination chain of 2 (e). In 2, each Dy­(III) ion is coordinated to six O atoms from three chelating acac– ions and two N atoms from two bpe ligands (d), leading again to a distorted D 4d (N2O6) coordination sphere. The square antiprism CShM value of Dy­(III) in 2 is 0.501 (), which is smaller than that of 1, indicating that the coordination geometry of the Dy­(III) center in 2 is closer to the reference (D 4d ) shape. Moreover, because of the coordination of the guest bpe from 1 to 2, the steric effect prompts the cooperative rearrangement of the other ligands, leading to a change of the coordination sphere ( and Tables S1 and S2). As the rearrangement of the negatively charged and the neutral ligands would undoubtedly change the crystal field of Dy­(III) ion, it is interesting to investigate its influence on magnetization dynamics from 1 to 2.
elements.clean_text: As expected, the single-crystal structure of 2 shows that the terminal methanol ligand was replaced by the hydrogen-bonded bpe molecules when heated, thus confirming the solid-state ligand substitution. After the coordination of the guest bpe molecules, the {Dy2} units in 1 are connected with each other, resulting in the one-dimensional (1D) coordination chain of 2 (e). In 2, each Dy(III) ion is coordinated to six O atoms from three chelating acac- ions and two N atoms from two bpe ligands (d), leading again to a distorted D 4d  (N2O6) coordination sphere. The square antiprism CShM value of Dy(III) in 2 is 0.501 (), which is smaller than that of 1, indicating that the coordination geometry of the Dy(III) center in 2 is closer to the reference (D 4d ) shape. Moreover, because of the coordination of the guest bpe from 1 to 2, the steric effect prompts the cooperative rearrangement of the other ligands, leading to a change of the coordination sphere ( and Tables S1 and S2). As the rearrangement of the negatively charged and the neutral ligands would undoubtedly change the crystal field of Dy(III) ion, it is interesting to investigate its influence on magnetization dynamics from 1 to 2.

elements.content: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were recorded in a direct-current (dc) field of 1 kOe (). At room temperature, χM T values of 13.8 cm3 K mol–1 are found for both 1 and 2, which are slightly smaller than the expected value of one Dy­(III) ion (14.2 cm3 K mol–1 for the 6H15/2 state). This could be ascribed to the fact that the ground Russell–Saunders multiplet is not equally populated even at room temperature. When cooled, the χM T values of 1 and 2 gradually decrease to 11.1 and 9.7 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, indicating the further depopulation of Stark sublevels of Dy­(III) ion and/or dipolar magnetic interactions. The magnetization at 2 K increases rapidly with the magnetic field strength up to ∼9 kOe and then increases slowly, finally reaching values of 5.22 Nβ for 1 and 5.93 Nβ for 2 at 70 kOe (Figure S3). Detailed ac susceptibility measurements were also performed on the crystalline samples of 1 and 2 obtained directly from the synthesis to study their dynamic behaviors.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were recorded in a direct-current (dc) field of 1 kOe (). At room temperature, χM T values of 13.8 cm3 K mol-1 are found for both 1 and 2, which are slightly smaller than the expected value of one Dy(III) ion (14.2 cm3 K mol-1 for the 6H15/2 state). This could be ascribed to the fact that the ground Russell-Saunders multiplet is not equally populated even at room temperature. When cooled, the χM T values of 1 and 2 gradually decrease to 11.1 and 9.7 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, indicating the further depopulation of Stark sublevels of Dy(III) ion and/or dipolar magnetic interactions. The magnetization at 2 K increases rapidly with the magnetic field strength up to ~9 kOe and then increases slowly, finally reaching values of 5.22 Nβ for 1 and 5.93 Nβ for 2 at 70 kOe (Figure S3). Detailed ac susceptibility measurements were also performed on the crystalline samples of 1 and 2 obtained directly from the synthesis to study their dynamic behaviors.

elements.content: Temperature-dependent χM T products at 1 kOe for 1 (red) and 2 (green). The solid lines correspond to the ab initio calculations. (inset) Plot of magnetization vs field for 1 (red) and 2 (green) at 2 K, respectively, with a sweep rate of 200 Oe s–1.
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature-dependent χM T products at 1 kOe for 1 (red) and 2 (green). The solid lines correspond to the ab initio calculations. (inset) Plot of magnetization vs field for 1 (red) and 2 (green) at 2 K, respectively, with a sweep rate of 200 Oe s-1.

elements.content: At zero field, the out-of-phase (χM″) alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility signals for both complexes are not observed due to the fast quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM), which could arise from crystal-field effect, hyperfine interaction, and dipolar interactions.
elements.clean_text: At zero field, the out-of-phase (χM") alternating-current (ac) magnetic susceptibility signals for both complexes are not observed due to the fast quantum tunneling of magnetization (QTM), which could arise from crystal-field effect, hyperfine interaction, and dipolar interactions.

elements.content: A series of external dc fields in the range of 0.2–5.0 kOe were applied to suppress the QTM process in 1 at 4 K and in 2 at 2 K. As a result, a set of peaks of χM″ signals at various fields is observed in the range of 0.1–1488 Hz for both complexes (Figure S4), indicating a slowing of relaxation processes. The optimized dc field is 1500 Oe for 1 and 800 Oe for 2 (Figure S5), respectively. The temperature-dependent ac susceptibility measurements () at the optimized dc fields for 1 and 2 were performed. No “tails” of the out-of-phase χM″ signals are observed for any complexes at low temperature, suggesting the suppression of QTM. At the ac frequency of 1488 Hz, the peaks of χM″ signals for 1 are observed at 12.5 K, higher than that of 2, which were obtained at a temperature of 4.3 K.
elements.clean_text: A series of external dc fields in the range of 0.2-5.0 kOe were applied to suppress the QTM process in 1 at 4 K and in 2 at 2 K. As a result, a set of peaks of χM" signals at various fields is observed in the range of 0.1-1488 Hz for both complexes (Figure S4), indicating a slowing of relaxation processes. The optimized dc field is 1500 Oe for 1 and 800 Oe for 2 (Figure S5), respectively. The temperature-dependent ac susceptibility measurements () at the optimized dc fields for 1 and 2 were performed. No "tails" of the out-of-phase χM" signals are observed for any complexes at low temperature, suggesting the suppression of QTM. At the ac frequency of 1488 Hz, the peaks of χM" signals for 1 are observed at 12.5 K, higher than that of 2, which were obtained at a temperature of 4.3 K.

elements.content: Temperature-dependent ac susceptibilities for 1 at a 1500 Oe (a) dc fields, and 2 under an 800 Oe dc field (b).
elements.clean_text: 4  Temperature-dependent ac susceptibilities for 1 at a 1500 Oe (a) dc fields, and 2 under an 800 Oe dc field (b).

elements.content: However, the frequency-dependent ac susceptibility (Figure S6), measured at 2 K, shows that the peaks of χM″ signals for 1 are located at the frequency region below 1 Hz, while those of 2 are located at 10.8 Hz, suggesting that the relaxation time for 1 is much longer than that for 2 at low-temperature region. The butterfly-shaped hysteresis loop of 1 at 2 K further confirms the slower relaxation process than that of 2 under an external field ( inset). The relaxation time (τ) of both complexes was also extracted by fitting the ac magnetic susceptibilities with a generalized Debye model (Figure S6b,d). The resulting distribution coefficient values (α) for 1 (>5 K) and 2 (>3 K) are in the range of 0–0.2, indicating the narrow-to-moderate distribution of slow magnetic relaxation. However, the α values increase to 0.38 for 1 (at 3 K) and 0.33 for 2 (at 2 K); these relatively large α values for both complexes at low-temperature region may be attributed to the onset of QTM. As shown in , the relaxation time τ for 1 is obviously longer than that of 2 at the same temperature. Obviously, the relaxation times for both complexes at the whole temperature region deviate from the Arrhenius law, indicating the presence of other relaxation pathways besides of Orbach processes. In fact, we found that the τ versus T data for both complexes can be properly fitted with an experimental τ –1 ∼ T n law (), which corresponds to a Raman process. Values of n = 6.4 and 7.2 were obtained for 1 and 2, respectively, indicating that a Raman process could also account for the entire relaxation behavior for both complexes.
elements.clean_text: However, the frequency-dependent ac susceptibility (Figure S6), measured at 2 K, shows that the peaks of χM" signals for 1 are located at the frequency region below 1 Hz, while those of 2 are located at 10.8 Hz, suggesting that the relaxation time for 1 is much longer than that for 2 at low-temperature region. The butterfly-shaped hysteresis loop of 1 at 2 K further confirms the slower relaxation process than that of 2 under an external field ( inset). The relaxation time (τ) of both complexes was also extracted by fitting the ac magnetic susceptibilities with a generalized Debye model (Figure S6b,d). The resulting distribution coefficient values (α) for 1 (>5 K) and 2 (>3 K) are in the range of 0-0.2, indicating the narrow-to-moderate distribution of slow magnetic relaxation. However, the α values increase to 0.38 for 1 (at 3 K) and 0.33 for 2 (at 2 K); these relatively large α values for both complexes at low-temperature region may be attributed to the onset of QTM. As shown in , the relaxation time τ for 1 is obviously longer than that of 2 at the same temperature. Obviously, the relaxation times for both complexes at the whole temperature region deviate from the Arrhenius law, indicating the presence of other relaxation pathways besides of Orbach processes. In fact, we found that the τ versus T data for both complexes can be properly fitted with an experimental τ -1 ~ T  n  law (), which corresponds to a Raman process. Values of n = 6.4 and 7.2 were obtained for 1 and 2, respectively, indicating that a Raman process could also account for the entire relaxation behavior for both complexes.

elements.content: Plots of ln τ vs T –1 for 1 (red) and 2 (green) at 1500 and 800 Oe fields, respectively. The solid lines represent the Raman process for 1 and 2 with a τ –1 ∼ T n law.
elements.clean_text: 5  Plots of ln τ vs T -1 for 1 (red) and 2 (green) at 1500 and 800 Oe fields, respectively. The solid lines represent the Raman process for 1 and 2 with a τ -1 ~ T  n  law.

elements.content: Detailed ac susceptibility measurements were also performed on the polycrystalline samples of 2, obtained from the solid-state ligand substitution reaction of 1, to compare to the directly obtained macrocrystalline samples of 2 under the same external dc fields (H dc = 800 Oe). As shown in Figure S7, the temperature- and frequency-dependent ac susceptibilities for the polycrystalline samples of 2 obtained by thermal treatment of 1 are very similar to the directly obtained macrocrystalline samples. Figure S8 shows that the temperature-dependent magnetic relaxation time of microcrystalline powders of 2 matches well with the directly obtained samples of 2 from the synthesis, confirming the structural transformation from 1 to 2 through solid-state ligand substitution reaction.
elements.clean_text: Detailed ac susceptibility measurements were also performed on the polycrystalline samples of 2, obtained from the solid-state ligand substitution reaction of 1, to compare to the directly obtained macrocrystalline samples of 2 under the same external dc fields (H dc = 800 Oe). As shown in Figure S7, the temperature- and frequency-dependent ac susceptibilities for the polycrystalline samples of 2 obtained by thermal treatment of 1 are very similar to the directly obtained macrocrystalline samples. Figure S8 shows that the temperature-dependent magnetic relaxation time of microcrystalline powders of 2 matches well with the directly obtained samples of 2 from the synthesis, confirming the structural transformation from 1 to 2 through solid-state ligand substitution reaction.

elements.content: The CASSCF calculated g-factors clearly show the large anisotropic character of these systems (g x , g y , g z of 1: 0.01, 0.03, 19.41; 2: 0.07, 0.29, 19.06). As reported in previous studies, the magnetic axiality of the ground Kramers’ doublet plays a key role for the SMM performance of single-lanthanide complexes. As may be observed, complex 1 possesses a larger axial component g z and smaller transverse components g x and g y than 2, suggesting a weaker quantum tunneling of magnetization for the former. The different coordination environment of the Dy­(III) center in both complexes entails a quite different direction of the magnetic moment for each of them (). In the case of complex 1, the magnetic moment seems to be aligned toward the axial oxygen atoms of two acac– ligands, probably because of the large metal–ligand electron repulsion in that direction due to the negative charge of the ligands. In comparison, the magnetic moment of complex 2 goes through the central carbon atom of one acac– ligand. This arrangement seems to minimize the metal–ligand electron repulsion in the equatorial plane of the complex. These results translate into a noticeable distortion of the β electron density obtained from the CASSCF ground state for both compounds, which takes a kind of oblate shape (). The different magnetic anisotropy axis for both complexes reveal the variation of coordination environment. As a consequence, the geometry distortion breaks the D 4d symmetry, leading to a deviation of the ground-state magnetic anisotropy axis of Dy­(III) ions from the C 4 axis. A similar observation has also been reported in a recent study on bis­(tetrapyrrole) dysprosium SMMs, where the easy axis of Dy­(III) ions clearly deviates from the C 4v axis by replacing one N atom of the porphyrin core by oxygen or sulfur atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Ab Initio Calculation

The CASSCF calculated g-factors clearly show the large anisotropic character of these systems (g  x , g  y , g  z  of 1: 0.01, 0.03, 19.41; 2: 0.07, 0.29, 19.06). As reported in previous studies, the magnetic axiality of the ground Kramers' doublet plays a key role for the SMM performance of single-lanthanide complexes. As may be observed, complex 1 possesses a larger axial component g  z  and smaller transverse components g  x  and g  y  than 2, suggesting a weaker quantum tunneling of magnetization for the former. The different coordination environment of the Dy(III) center in both complexes entails a quite different direction of the magnetic moment for each of them (). In the case of complex 1, the magnetic moment seems to be aligned toward the axial oxygen atoms of two acac- ligands, probably because of the large metal-ligand electron repulsion in that direction due to the negative charge of the ligands. In comparison, the magnetic moment of complex 2 goes through the central carbon atom of one acac- ligand. This arrangement seems to minimize the metal-ligand electron repulsion in the equatorial plane of the complex. These results translate into a noticeable distortion of the β electron density obtained from the CASSCF ground state for both compounds, which takes a kind of oblate shape (). The different magnetic anisotropy axis for both complexes reveal the variation of coordination environment. As a consequence, the geometry distortion breaks the D 4d  symmetry, leading to a deviation of the ground-state magnetic anisotropy axis of Dy(III) ions from the C 4 axis. A similar observation has also been reported in a recent study on bis(tetrapyrrole) dysprosium SMMs, where the easy axis of Dy(III) ions clearly deviates from the C 4v  axis by replacing one N atom of the porphyrin core by oxygen or sulfur atoms.

elements.content: Beta spin density isosurface (orange) of the Dy­(III) f-electrons found in the ab initio spin-free CASSCF calculation for complexes 1 (a) and 2 (b). The direction of the magnetic moment of the ground state obtained with MOLCAS and MAGELLAN are indicated as a green and a violet arrow, respectively (Color code: C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H atoms were omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 6  Beta spin density isosurface (orange) of the Dy(III) f-electrons found in the ab initio spin-free CASSCF calculation for complexes 1 (a) and 2 (b). The direction of the magnetic moment of the ground state obtained with MOLCAS and MAGELLAN are indicated as a green and a violet arrow, respectively (Color code: C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H atoms were omitted for clarity).

elements.content: Additionally, we also adopted the electrostatic model implemented in the MAGELLAN program, which has been developed extensively in the {Dy­(acac)3(L) x } motifs to predict the orientation of the ground-state magnetic anisotropy axis. Obviously, the directions of resulting electrostatic anisotropy axes for both complexes are very close to those from ab initio calculations.
elements.clean_text: Additionally, we also adopted the electrostatic model implemented in the MAGELLAN program, which has been developed extensively in the {Dy(acac)3(L) x } motifs to predict the orientation of the ground-state magnetic anisotropy axis. Obviously, the directions of resulting electrostatic anisotropy axes for both complexes are very close to those from ab initio calculations.

elements.content: The calculated energies of the lowest three Kramers’ doublets (KDs) for both complexes are represented in . The spin relaxation mechanisms indicate a plausible reversal of the magnetization through the first excited state because of an existing thermally assisted-quantum tunneling process, which should be more efficient for compound 2. In the case of this latter compound an Orbach relaxation process through the first KD could be also considered. Thus, the computed energy barriers enabling the spin relaxation should be 121.9 and 66.7 cm–1 for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. For comparison, the effective energy barriers (U eff) were extracted from the relaxation time data at the higher temperature region using an Arrhenius law. Values of U eff = 71.7 cm–1 and τ0 = 3.37 × 10–8 s for 1 and U eff = 33.7 cm–1 and τ0 = 1.39 × 10–9 s for 2 were found (Figure S7). As may be observed, the U eff obtained by fitting the magnetic data are smaller than those predicted by ab initio calculation, further indicating that the magnetization reversal should be preferentially attributed to a Raman mechanism () rather than to an Orbach process.
elements.clean_text: The calculated energies of the lowest three Kramers' doublets (KDs) for both complexes are represented in . The spin relaxation mechanisms indicate a plausible reversal of the magnetization through the first excited state because of an existing thermally assisted-quantum tunneling process, which should be more efficient for compound 2. In the case of this latter compound an Orbach relaxation process through the first KD could be also considered. Thus, the computed energy barriers enabling the spin relaxation should be 121.9 and 66.7 cm-1 for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. For comparison, the effective energy barriers (U eff) were extracted from the relaxation time data at the higher temperature region using an Arrhenius law. Values of U eff = 71.7 cm-1 and τ0 = 3.37 × 10-8 s for 1 and U eff = 33.7 cm-1 and τ0 = 1.39 × 10-9 s for 2 were found (Figure S7). As may be observed, the U eff obtained by fitting the magnetic data are smaller than those predicted by ab initio calculation, further indicating that the magnetization reversal should be preferentially attributed to a Raman mechanism () rather than to an Orbach process.

elements.content: Lowest three Kramers doublets and ab initio computed relaxation mechanism in 1 (upper) and 2 (lower). The thick black lines represent KDs as a function of their magnetic moment along the main anisotropy axis. Red lines indicate magnetization reversal mechanism. Blue lines correspond to ground-state QTM and thermally assisted-QTM via the first and second excited KDs; green (and orange) lines show possible Orbach relaxation processes. The values indicated close to the arrows indicate the matrix elements of the transition magnetic moments (values higher than 0.1 provide efficient spin relaxation mechanisms).
elements.clean_text: 7  Lowest three Kramers doublets and ab initio computed relaxation mechanism in 1 (upper) and 2 (lower). The thick black lines represent KDs as a function of their magnetic moment along the main anisotropy axis. Red lines indicate magnetization reversal mechanism. Blue lines correspond to ground-state QTM and thermally assisted-QTM via the first and second excited KDs; green (and orange) lines show possible Orbach relaxation processes. The values indicated close to the arrows indicate the matrix elements of the transition magnetic moments (values higher than 0.1 provide efficient spin relaxation mechanisms).

elements.content: In conclusion, we have employed the solid-state ligand substitution reaction to transform the dinuclear Dy­(III) compound [Dy2(acac)6(bpe)­(MeOH)2]·bpe·2MeOH (1) into the {Dy} n chain compound [Dy­(acac)3(bpe)] (2). This reaction takes advantage of the potential coordination ability of the guest bpe ligands of compound 1. The ac magnetic susceptibility measurements for compound 2 samples, both from synthesis and after the solid-state ligand substitution reaction, confirm the effective transformation of 1 into 2. The rearrangement of the acac– anions, methanol, and bpe ligands around the Dy­(III) centers in the solid-state transformation results in a remarkable change in the SMM behavior between both complexes. This work paves the way for fine-tuning of the magnetization dynamics of single-molecule magnets via a solid-state chemical substitution reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have employed the solid-state ligand substitution reaction to transform the dinuclear Dy(III) compound [Dy2(acac)6(bpe)(MeOH)2]⋅bpe⋅2MeOH (1) into the {Dy} n  chain compound [Dy(acac)3(bpe)] (2). This reaction takes advantage of the potential coordination ability of the guest bpe ligands of compound 1. The ac magnetic susceptibility measurements for compound 2 samples, both from synthesis and after the solid-state ligand substitution reaction, confirm the effective transformation of 1 into 2. The rearrangement of the acac- anions, methanol, and bpe ligands around the Dy(III) centers in the solid-state transformation results in a remarkable change in the SMM behavior between both complexes. This work paves the way for fine-tuning of the magnetization dynamics of single-molecule magnets via a solid-state chemical substitution reaction.

cln_elements.content:
[Dy2(acac)6(bpe)­(MeOH)2]·bpe·2MeOH (1). A mixture of Dy­(acac)3 (0.1 mmol) and bpe (0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 0.5 mL of MeOH. After it was stirred for ∼10 min, the resulting suspension was filtered. The filtrate was sealed in a 5 mL glass tube. Colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained for several hours at 5 °C. Yield: 76% based on Dy­(acac)3. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H60Dy2N2O14: C: 49.33, H: 5.57, N: 3.97; found (%): C: 49.43, H: 5.36, N: 3.72.

[Dy­(acac)3(bpe)] n (2) A mixture of Dy­(acac)3 (0.1 mmol) and bpe (0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 0.5 mL of MeOH. After it was stirred for ∼10 min, the resulting suspension solution was filtered. The filtrate was layered by 0.5 mL of isopropanol solution with 0.07 mmol bpe and then was sealed in a 5 mL glass tube. Colorless plate crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained after several hours at 5 °C. Yield: 69% based on Dy­(acac)3. Anal. Calcd (%) for C27H31DyN2O6: C: 50.51, H: 4.87, N: 4.36; found (%): C: 50.41, H: 4.94, N: 4.42.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[Dy2(acac)6(bpe)(MeOH)2]⋅bpe⋅2MeOH (1). A mixture of Dy(acac)3 (0.1 mmol) and bpe (0.2 mmol) was dissolved in 0.5 mL of MeOH. After it was stirred for ~10 min, the resulting suspension was filtered. The filtrate was sealed in a 5 mL glass tube. Colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained for several hours at 5 °C. Yield: 76% based on Dy(acac)3. Anal. Calcd (%) for C44H60Dy2N2O14: C: 49.33, H: 5.57, N: 3.97; found (%): C: 49.43, H: 5.36, N: 3.72.

[Dy(acac)3(bpe)] n  (2) A mixture of Dy(acac)3 (0.1 mmol) and bpe (0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 0.5 mL of MeOH. After it was stirred for ~10 min, the resulting suspension solution was filtered. The filtrate was layered by 0.5 mL of isopropanol solution with 0.07 mmol bpe and then was sealed in a 5 mL glass tube. Colorless plate crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained after several hours at 5 °C. Yield: 69% based on Dy(acac)3. Anal. Calcd (%) for C27H31DyN2O6: C: 50.51, H: 4.87, N: 4.36; found (%): C: 50.41, H: 4.94, N: 4.42.

cln_elements.content:
Considering the coordination potential of the guest bpe molecules and that they have free nitrogen donor atoms, we speculate a solid-state ligand substitution reaction, where the methanol ligand could be replaced by bpe. This kind of reaction has already been observed in some flexible frameworks with specific oriented host–guest interactions. The thermogravimetry (TG) and the variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) were measured to probe such solid-state ligand replacement. When heated, complex 1 suffers a mass loss of 9.42% at ∼60 °C (Figure S2), which agrees with the complete desolvation of the coordinated and the guest MeOH molecules (9.07%). Moreover, the VT-PXRD further indicates the crystal transformation from 1 to a new complex above 65 °C (). Although the single crystallinity of 1 was lost during the structural transformation, luckily, through the change of synthetic condition (see ), the single crystals of complex 2 () suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The PXRD experiment (Figures S1 and S2) confirms that the as-synthesized complex 2 and the TG transformed powder are identical.

Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were recorded in a direct-current (dc) field of 1 kOe (). At room temperature, χM T values of 13.8 cm3 K mol–1 are found for both 1 and 2, which are slightly smaller than the expected value of one Dy­(III) ion (14.2 cm3 K mol–1 for the 6H15/2 state). This could be ascribed to the fact that the ground Russell–Saunders multiplet is not equally populated even at room temperature. When cooled, the χM T values of 1 and 2 gradually decrease to 11.1 and 9.7 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, indicating the further depopulation of Stark sublevels of Dy­(III) ion and/or dipolar magnetic interactions. The magnetization at 2 K increases rapidly with the magnetic field strength up to ∼9 kOe and then increases slowly, finally reaching values of 5.22 Nβ for 1 and 5.93 Nβ for 2 at 70 kOe (Figure S3). Detailed ac susceptibility measurements were also performed on the crystalline samples of 1 and 2 obtained directly from the synthesis to study their dynamic behaviors.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Considering the coordination potential of the guest bpe molecules and that they have free nitrogen donor atoms, we speculate a solid-state ligand substitution reaction, where the methanol ligand could be replaced by bpe. This kind of reaction has already been observed in some flexible frameworks with specific oriented host-guest interactions. The thermogravimetry (TG) and the variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) were measured to probe such solid-state ligand replacement. When heated, complex 1 suffers a mass loss of 9.42% at ~60 °C (Figure S2), which agrees with the complete desolvation of the coordinated and the guest MeOH molecules (9.07%). Moreover, the VT-PXRD further indicates the crystal transformation from 1 to a new complex above 65 °C (). Although the single crystallinity of 1 was lost during the structural transformation, luckily, through the change of synthetic condition (see ), the single crystals of complex 2 () suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. The PXRD experiment (Figures S1 and S2) confirms that the as-synthesized complex 2 and the TG transformed powder are identical.

Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were recorded in a direct-current (dc) field of 1 kOe (). At room temperature, χM T values of 13.8 cm3 K mol-1 are found for both 1 and 2, which are slightly smaller than the expected value of one Dy(III) ion (14.2 cm3 K mol-1 for the 6H15/2 state). This could be ascribed to the fact that the ground Russell-Saunders multiplet is not equally populated even at room temperature. When cooled, the χM T values of 1 and 2 gradually decrease to 11.1 and 9.7 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, indicating the further depopulation of Stark sublevels of Dy(III) ion and/or dipolar magnetic interactions. The magnetization at 2 K increases rapidly with the magnetic field strength up to ~9 kOe and then increases slowly, finally reaching values of 5.22 Nβ for 1 and 5.93 Nβ for 2 at 70 kOe (Figure S3). Detailed ac susceptibility measurements were also performed on the crystalline samples of 1 and 2 obtained directly from the synthesis to study their dynamic behaviors.

[^1]: SAPR-8 = square antiprism; TDD-8 = triangular dodecahedron.

The direction of the magnetic moment of the ground state obtained with MOLCAS and MAGELLAN are indicated as a green and a violet arrow, respectively (Color code: C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H atoms were omitted for clarity).
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Beta spin density isosurface (orange) of the Dy(III) f-electrons found in the ab initio spin-free CASSCF calculation for complexes 1 (a) and 2 (b). The direction of the magnetic moment of the ground state obtained with MOLCAS and MAGELLAN are indicated as a green and a violet arrow, respectively (Color code: C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H atoms were omitted for clarity).

cln_elements.content: Lowest three Kramers doublets and ab initio computed relaxation mechanism in 1 (upper) and 2 (lower). The thick black lines represent KDs as a function of their magnetic moment along the main anisotropy axis. Red lines indicate magnetization reversal mechanism. Blue lines correspond to ground-state QTM and thermally assisted-QTM via the first and second excited KDs; green (and orange) lines show possible Orbach relaxation processes. The values indicated close to the arrows indicate the matrix elements of the transition magnetic moments (values higher than 0.1 provide efficient spin relaxation mechanisms).
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Lowest three Kramers doublets and ab initio computed relaxation mechanism in 1 (upper) and 2 (lower). The thick black lines represent KDs as a function of their magnetic moment along the main anisotropy axis. Red lines indicate magnetization reversal mechanism. Blue lines correspond to ground-state QTM and thermally assisted-QTM via the first and second excited KDs; green (and orange) lines show possible Orbach relaxation processes. The values indicated close to the arrows indicate the matrix elements of the transition magnetic moments (values higher than 0.1 provide efficient spin relaxation mechanisms).

metadata.title:
Tunable Magnetization Dynamics through Solid-State
Ligand Substitution Reaction
